25:T1c5f,<entryFree id="n40251" key="نَفُسَ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>1</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">نَفُسَ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form>, aor.      
    <form n="infl">       
                     <orth orig="Bu" lang="ar">نَفُسَ</orth>
                  </form>, inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">نَفَاسَةٌ</foreign> (S, M, A, Msb, K) and <foreign lang="ar">نِفَاسٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">نَفسٌ</foreign> (K) and <foreign lang="ar">نُفُوسٌ</foreign>; (TA;) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n40251-1" target="أَنْفَسَ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>, (M, A, Msb,) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">إِنْفَاسٌ</foreign>; (A, Msb;) <hi rend="ital">It was,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">became, high in estimation, of high account,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">excellent;</hi> (M, Msb, TA;) [<hi rend="ital">highly prized; precious,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">valuable;</hi>] <hi rend="ital">and therefore,</hi> (TA,) <hi rend="ital">was desired with emulation,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">in much request:</hi> (S, K, TA:) and the ↓ latter verb, said of property, <hi rend="ital">it was,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">became, loved, and highly esteemed.</hi> (TA.)       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">نَفِسَ بِهِ</foreign>, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor.      
    <form n="infl">       
                     <orth orig="Ba" lang="ar">نَفَسَ</orth>
                  </form>, (K,) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">نَفَسٌ</foreign> (M) [and app. <foreign lang="ar">نَفْسٌ</foreign> as will be shown below] and <foreign lang="ar">نَفَاسَةٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">نَفَاسِيَةٌ</foreign>, which last is extr., (M, TA,) <hi rend="ital">He was,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">became avaricious, tenacious,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">niggardly, of it,</hi> (S, M, Msb, K,) <hi rend="ital">because of its being in high estimation,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">excellent.</hi> (Msb.) Hence the saying in the Kur, [xlvii. 40,] <foreign lang="ar">فَإِنَّمَا يَبْخَلُ عَنْ نَفْسِهِ</foreign> [app. meaning <hi rend="ital">He is only avaricious from his avarice.</hi>] (TA.) You say, <foreign lang="ar">نَفِسَ عَلَيْهِ بِالشَّىْءِ</foreign>, (M,) or <foreign lang="ar">عَنْهُ</foreign> [in the place of <foreign lang="ar">عليه</foreign>], (TA,) <hi rend="ital">He was,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">became, avaricious,</hi> &amp;c., <hi rend="ital">of the thing, towards him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">withholding it from him.</hi> (M, TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">نَفِسَ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">عَلَيْهِ الشَّىْءَ</foreign>, (S, M, K, TA,) and <foreign lang="ar">بِالشَّىْءِ</foreign>, (M,) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">نَفَاسَةٌ</foreign>. (S, K, TA,) <hi rend="ital">He was,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">became, avaricious,</hi> &amp;c., <hi rend="ital">of the thing, towards him, and thought him not worthy of it, and was not pleased at its coming to him:</hi> (TA:) or [simply] <hi rend="ital">he thought him not worthy of it:</hi> (S, M, K;) as also <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n40251-2" target="نافسهُ" n="2" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>فِيهِ</foreign>; of which last verb we have an ex. in the phrase <foreign lang="ar">تُنَافِسُ دُنْيَا</foreign>, used by a poet in speaking of the tribe of Kureysh, meaning either <foreign lang="ar">تُنَافِسُ فِى دُنْبَا</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">they think</hi> others <hi rend="ital">not worthy of worldly good</hi>]. or <foreign lang="ar">تُنَافسُ أَهْلَ دُنْيَا</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">they think the possessors of worldly good unworthy</hi> thereof]. (M.) [See also 3, below.] You say also, <foreign lang="ar">نَفِسْتَ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">عَلَىَّ بِخَيْرٍ</foreign>, (A, K,) or <foreign lang="ar">بِخَيْرٍ قَلِيل</foreign>, (S,) and <foreign lang="ar">نَفِسْتَ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">عَلَىَّ خَيْرًا كَثِيرًا</foreign>, (A,) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">نَفْسٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">نَفَاسَةٌ</foreign>, (A,) <hi rend="ital">Thou enviedst me</hi> (S, A, K) <hi rend="ital">good,</hi> (A, K,) or <hi rend="ital">a little good,</hi> (S,) and <hi rend="ital">much good,</hi> (A.) <hi rend="ital">and didst not consider me worthy of it.</hi> (A.) And <foreign lang="ar">فُلَانٌ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">مَا يَتَنَغَّسُ عَلَيْنَا الغَنِيمَةَ وَالظَّفَرَ</foreign> [app. meaning <hi rend="ital">Such a one does not envy us the spoil and the victory.</hi>] (A, in continuation of what here immediately precedes.) And <foreign lang="ar">مَا هٰذَا النَّفَسُ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">What is this envying?</hi> (A, TA.)       <sense type="A" n="3">-A3-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">نُفِسَتْ</foreign>; (S, M, A, Msb, K;) and <foreign lang="ar">نَفِسَتْ</foreign>, (S, M, Msb, K,) as some of the Arabs say, (Msb.) aor. <form n="infl"><orth orig="Ba"/></form>, (Msb, K:) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">نِفَاسٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">نِفَاسةٌ</foreign> (S, M) and <foreign lang="ar">نَفَسٌ</foreign>, (M, TA,) or the first of these ns. is a simple subst.; (Msb;) <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">She</hi> (a woman) <hi rend="ital">brought forth;</hi> (S, M, K;) and <foreign lang="ar">نُفِسَتْ وَلَدًا</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">she brought forth a child</hi>]: (Th, M:) and <foreign lang="ar">نُفِسَتْ بِوَلَدِهَا</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">she brought forth her child</hi>]. (A.) You say also, <foreign lang="ar">وَرِث فُلَانٌ هٰذَا قَبْلَ أَنْ يَنْفَسَ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">فُلَانٌ</foreign>, meaning, <hi rend="ital">Such a one inherited this before such a one was born.</hi> (S.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  Also, both these verbs, (Msb, K,) or the latter, <foreign lang="ar">نَفِسَتْ</foreign>, only, (Az, Mgh, TA,) or the latter is the more common, (K.) the former, which is related on the authority of As, not being well known, (Msb,) <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">She</hi> (a woman) <hi rend="ital">menstruated.</hi> (Az, Mgh, Msb, K.) [In the CK, a confusion is made by the omission of a <foreign lang="ar">و</foreign> before the verb which explains this last signification.] This signification and that next preceding it are from <foreign lang="ar">نَفْسٌ</foreign> meaning “ blood. ” (Mgh.)       <sense type="A" n="4">-A4-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">نَفَسْتُهُ بِنَفْسِ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">I smote him with an</hi> [<hi rend="ital">evil</hi> or <hi rend="ital">envious</hi>] <hi rend="ital">eye.</hi> (S, K, TA.)    </entryFree>26:Ta03,<entryFree id="n40252" key="نفّسهُ فِيهِ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>2</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">نفّسهُ فِيهِ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form>, or <foreign lang="ar">بِهِ</foreign>: see 4.       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">نفّس كُرْبَتَهُ</foreign>, (A, Mgh, Msb, K, *) and <foreign lang="ar">نفّس عَنْهُ كُرْبَتَهُ</foreign>, (S,) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">تَنْفِيسٌ</foreign> (S, Msb, K) and [quasi-inf. n.] <foreign lang="ar">نَفَسٌ</foreign>, (K,) <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">He</hi> (God) <hi rend="ital">removed,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">cleared away, his grief,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">sorrow,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">anxiety:</hi> (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K *:) and <foreign lang="ar">نفّس عَنْهُ</foreign> signifies the same; (M, Mgh;) and <hi rend="ital">He made his circumstances ample and easy;</hi> (M, TA;) and <hi rend="ital">he</hi> (a man) <hi rend="ital">eased him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">relieved him,</hi> syn. <foreign lang="ar">رَفَّهَ</foreign>: (S, TA:) and also, this last phrase, <hi rend="ital">he granted him a delay:</hi> the objective compliment being omitted: and <foreign lang="ar">نَفِّسْنِى</foreign> is used as meaning <hi rend="ital">grant thou to me a delay:</hi> or, elliptically, <foreign lang="ar">نَفِّسْ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">كَرْبِى</foreign> or <foreign lang="ar">غَمِّى</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">remove thou my grief,</hi> &amp;c.]. (Mgh.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  [Hence] <foreign lang="ar">حَرْفُ تَنْفِيسٍ</foreign>, applied to the prefix <foreign lang="ar">سَ</foreign> [and its variants <foreign lang="ar">سَوْفَ</foreign> &amp;c.], meaning <hi rend="ital">A particle of amplification;</hi> because changing the aor. from the strait time which is the present, to the ample time, which is the future. (Mughnee, in art. <foreign lang="ar">س</foreign>.)       <sense type="A" n="3">-A3-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">نفّس القَوْسَ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">He cracked the bow:</hi> (Kr. M:) [see 5:] accord. to ISh, <hi rend="ital">he put</hi> (<foreign lang="ar">حَطَّ</foreign>) <hi rend="ital">its string</hi> [<hi rend="ital">upon the bow</hi>]. (TA.)    </entryFree>27:T976,<entryFree id="n40253" key="نافس فِى الشَّىْءِ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>3</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">نافس فِى الشَّىْءِ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form>, (S, K. *) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">مُنَافَسَةٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">نِفَاسٌ</foreign>, (S,) <hi rend="ital">He desired the thing,</hi> [or <hi rend="ital">aspired to it.</hi>] <hi rend="ital">with generous emulation;</hi> (S, K;) as also   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n40253-1" target="تنافس" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n40255"/></foreign>: (K:) and <foreign lang="ar">نافس صَاحِبَهُ فِيهِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">he vied with his companion in desire for it</hi>]: (A:) or <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n40253-2" target="تنافسوا" n="2" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar" select="n40255"/>فيه</foreign> signifies <hi rend="ital">they desired it</hi> [or <hi rend="ital">aspired to it</hi>]: (S:) or <hi rend="ital">they vied, one with another, in desiring it:</hi> or <hi rend="ital">they desired it with emulation;</hi> syn. <foreign lang="ar">فَراغَبَوا</foreign>: (A, TA:) [and <foreign lang="ar">يُنَنَافسُ فيه</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">it is emulously desired,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">in request;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">in great request:</hi>] or <foreign lang="ar">مُنَافَسَهٌ</foreign> and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n40253-3" target="تَنَافُسٌ" n="3" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> signify the <hi rend="ital">desiring to have a thing, and to have it for himself exclusively of any other person;</hi> from <foreign lang="ar">نَفِيسٌ</foreign>, signifying a thing “ good, or goodly, or excellent, in its kind: ” (TA:) and <foreign lang="ar">تَنَافَسْنَا ذٰلِكَ الأَمْرَ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">تنافسنا فيه</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">we envied one another for that thing, and strove for priority in attaining it.</hi> (M.) See also <foreign lang="ar">تَفِسَ عَلَيْهِ الشَّىْءَ</foreign>, with which <foreign lang="ar">نَافَسَهُ فِيهِ</foreign> is syn. (M.)    </entryFree>28:T4c9,<entryFree id="n40254" key="انفس" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>4</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">انفس</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form>: see <foreign lang="ar">نَفُسَ</foreign>, in two places.       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">انفسهُ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">It</hi> (a thing, TA) <hi rend="ital">pleased him,</hi> (K, TA,) <hi rend="ital">and made him desirous of it:</hi> (TA:) or <hi rend="ital">became highly esteemed by him.</hi> (IKtt.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">أَنْفَسَنى فِيهِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">He made me desirous of it;</hi> (S, M, A, K:) as also <foreign lang="ar">تَفَّسَنِى فيه</foreign>, (IAar, M, TA,) or <foreign lang="ar">بِهِ</foreign>. (So in my copy of the A.)       <sense type="A" n="3">-A3-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">مَا أَنْفَسَهُ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">How powerful is his evil,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">envious, eye!</hi> (Lh, M.)    </entryFree>29:T115c,<entryFree id="n40255" key="تنفّس" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>5</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">تنفّس</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> [<hi rend="ital">He breathed</hi>] is said of a man and of every animal having lungs: (S:) [or it signifies] <hi rend="ital">he drew</hi> (<foreign lang="ar">اِسْتَمَدَّ</foreign>) <hi rend="ital">breath:</hi> (M:) or [<hi rend="ital">he respired,</hi> i. e.] <hi rend="ital">he drew breath with the air-passages in his nose; to his inside, and emitted it.</hi> (Msb.) You say also, <foreign lang="ar">تنفّس الصُّعَدَآءَ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">He sighed:</hi> see also art. <foreign lang="ar">صعد</foreign>]. (S.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">He</hi> (a man) <hi rend="ital">emitted wind from beneath him.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  Also, (TA,) or <foreign lang="ar">تنفّس</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">فِى الإِنَآءِ</foreign>, (K,) <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">He drank</hi> (K, TA) <hi rend="ital">from the vessel</hi> (TA) <hi rend="ital">with three restings between draughts, and separated the vessel from his mouth at every such resting:</hi> (K, TA.) and, contr., the latter phrase, <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">he drank</hi> [<hi rend="ital">from the vessel</hi>] <hi rend="ital">without separating it from his mouth:</hi> (K, TA:) which latter mode of drinking is disapproved. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  Also <foreign lang="ar">تنفّس</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">He lengthened in speech; he spoke long;</hi> for when a speaker takes breath, it is easy <pb n="2827"/> to him to lengthen his speech; and <foreign lang="ar">تنفس فِى</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">الكَلَامِ</foreign> signifies the same. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="5">-b5-</sense>  <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">It</hi> (said of the day, M, A, and of the dawn, A, and of other things, M) <hi rend="ital">became extended;</hi> (M;) <hi rend="ital">it became long;</hi> (M, A;) or, said of the day, accord. to Lh, <hi rend="ital">it advanced so that it became noon:</hi> (M:) or <hi rend="ital">it increased:</hi> (S:) and <hi rend="ital">it extended far:</hi> and hence it is said of life, meaning either <hi rend="ital">it became protracted, and extended far,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">it became ample:</hi> (M:) and, said of the dawn, <hi rend="ital">it shone forth,</hi> (Akh, S, K, TA,) <hi rend="ital">and extended so that it became clear day:</hi> (Fr, TA:) or <hi rend="ital">it broke, so that things became plain in consequence of it:</hi> (TA:) or <hi rend="ital">it rose:</hi> (Mujáhid:) or <hi rend="ital">its dusty hue shone at the approach of a gentle wind.</hi> (Bd, lxxxi. 18.) You say also, <foreign lang="ar">تنفّس بِهِ العُمُرُ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  [<hi rend="ital">Life became long,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">protracted,</hi> &amp;c., <hi rend="ital">with him</hi>]. (A.) And <foreign lang="ar">تنفّست دِجْلَةُ</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">The water of the Tigris increased.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="6">-b6-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">تنفّس</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">المَوْجُ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">The waves sprinkled the water.</hi> (S, K.)          <sense type="b" n="7">-b7-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">تنفّست القَوْسُ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">The bow cracked.</hi> (S, M, K.) It is only the stick that is not split in twain that does so; and this is the best of bows. And <foreign lang="ar">تنفّس</foreign> in the same sense is said of an arrow. (M.)       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  [<foreign lang="ar">تنفّس عَلَيْهِ الشَّىْءَ</foreign> app. signifies the same as <foreign lang="ar">نَفِسَ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">عليه الشىء</foreign>, q. v.]    </entryFree>2a:T5911,<entryFree id="n40256" key="نَفْسٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">نَفْسٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> The <hi rend="ital">soul;</hi> the <hi rend="ital">spirit;</hi> the <hi rend="ital">vital principle;</hi> syn. <foreign lang="ar">رُوحٌ</foreign>: (S, M, A, Msb, K:) but between these two words is a difference [which must be fully explained hereafter, though ISd says, that it is not of the purpose of his book, the M, to explain it]: (M:) in this sense it is fem.: (Msb:) pl. [of pauc.] <foreign lang="ar">أَنْفُسٌ</foreign> and [of mult.] <foreign lang="ar">نُفُوسٌ</foreign>. (M, Msb.) You say, <foreign lang="ar">خَرَجَتْ نَفْسُهُ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">His soul,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">spirit, went forth</hi>]; (Aboo-Is-hák, S, M, Msb, K;) and so <foreign lang="ar">جَادَتْ نَفْسُهُ</foreign>. (Msb.) And a poet says, not Aboo-Khirásh as in the S, but Hudheyfeh Ibn-Anas, (IB,) <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">نَجَا سَالِمٌ والنَّفْسُ مِنْهُ بِشِدْقِهِ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">وَلَمْ يَنْجُ إِلَّا جَفْنَ سَيْفٍ وَمِئْزَرَا</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> i. e., [<hi rend="ital">Sálim escaped when the soul was in the side of his mouth; but he escaped not save</hi>] <hi rend="ital">with the scabbard of a sword and with a waist-wrapper.</hi> (S.) In the same sense the word is used in the saying. <foreign lang="ar">فِى نَفْسِ فُلَانٍ أَنْ يَفْعَلَ كَذَا وَكَذَا</foreign> [but this seems rather to mean, <hi rend="ital">It is in the mind of such a one to do so and so</hi>]. (Aboo-Is-hák, M.) Some of the lexicologists assert the <foreign lang="ar">نَفْس</foreign> and the <foreign lang="ar">رُوح</foreign> to be one and the same, except that the former is fem., and the latter [generally or often] masc.: others say, that the latter is that whereby is life; and the former, <hi rend="ital">that whereby is intellect,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">reason;</hi> so that when one sleeps, God takes away his <foreign lang="ar">نفس</foreign>, but not his <foreign lang="ar">روح</foreign>, which is not taken save at death: and the <foreign lang="ar">نَفْس</foreign> is thus called because of its connexion with the <foreign lang="ar">نَفَس</foreign> [or breath]. (IAmb.) Or every man has <foreign lang="ar">نَفْسَانِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">two souls</hi>]: (I'Ab, Zj:) <foreign lang="ar">نَفْسُ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">العَقْلِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">the soul of intellect,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">reason,</hi> also called <foreign lang="ar">النَّفْسُ النَّاطِقَةُ</foreign> (see <foreign lang="ar">رُوحٌ</foreign>)], <hi rend="ital">whereby one discriminates,</hi> [i. e., <hi rend="ital">the mind,</hi>] (I'Ab,) or <foreign lang="ar">نَفْسُ التَّمْيِيزِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">the soul of discrimination</hi>], which quits him when he sleeps, so that he does not understand thereby, God taking it away: (Zj:) and <foreign lang="ar">نَفْسُ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">الرُّوحِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">the soul of the breath</hi>], <hi rend="ital">whereby one lives,</hi> (I'Ab,) or <foreign lang="ar">نَفْسُ الحَيَاةِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">the soul of life</hi>], and when this quits him, the breath quits with it; whereas the sleeper breathes: and this is the difference between the taking away of the <foreign lang="ar">نفس</foreign> of the sleeper in sleep and the taking away of the <foreign lang="ar">نفس</foreign> of the living [at death.] (Zj.) Much has been said respecting the <foreign lang="ar">نَفْس</foreign> and the <foreign lang="ar">رُوح</foreign>; whether they be one, or different: but the truth is, that there is a difference between them, since they are not always interchangeable: for it is said in the Kur, [xv. 29 and xxxviii. 72,] <foreign lang="ar">وَنَفَخْتُ فِيهِ مِنْ رُوحِى</foreign> [And I have blown into him of my spirit.]; not <foreign lang="ar">مِنْ نَفْسِى</foreign>: and [v. 116,] <foreign lang="ar">تَعْلَمُ مَا فِى نَفْسِى</foreign> [to be explained hereafter]; not <foreign lang="ar">فِى رُوحِى</foreign>, nor would this expression be well except from Jesus: and [lviii. 9,] <foreign lang="ar">وَيَقُولُونَ فِى</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">أَنْفُسِهِمْ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">And they say in their souls,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">within themselves</hi>]: for which it would not be well to say <foreign lang="ar">فِى أَرْوَاحِهِمْ</foreign>: and [xxxix. 57,] <foreign lang="ar">أَنْ تَقُولَ نَفْسٌ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">That a soul shall say</hi>]; for which no Arab would say <foreign lang="ar">أَنْ تَقُولَ رُوحٌ</foreign>: hence, the difference between them depends upon the considerations of relation: and this is indicated by a trad., in which it is said that God created Adam, and put into him a <foreign lang="ar">نَفْس</foreign> and a <foreign lang="ar">رُوح</foreign>; and that from the latter was his quality of abstaining from unlawful and indecorous things, and his understanding, and his clemency, or forbearance, and his liberality, and his fidelity; and from the former, [which is also called <foreign lang="ar">النَّفْسُ الأَمَّارَةُ</foreign>, q. v., in art. <foreign lang="ar">أمر</foreign>,] his appetence, and his unsteadiness, and his hastiness of disposition, and his anger: therefore one should not say that <foreign lang="ar">نَفْسٌ</foreign> is the same as <foreign lang="ar">رُوحٌ</foreign> absolutely, without restriction, nor <foreign lang="ar">رُوحٌ</foreign> the same as <foreign lang="ar">نَفْس</foreign>. (R.) The Arabs also make the discriminative <foreign lang="ar">نَفْس</foreign> to be two; because it sometimes commands the man to do a thing or forbids him to do it; and this is on the occasion of setting about an affair that is disliked: therefore they make that which commands him to be a <foreign lang="ar">نفس</foreign>, and that which forbids him to be as though it were another <foreign lang="ar">نفس</foreign>: and hence the saying, mentioned by Z, <foreign lang="ar">فُلَانٌ يُؤَامِرُ نَفْسَيْهِ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  [<hi rend="ital">Such a one consults his two souls,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">minds</hi>]; said of a man when two opinions occur to him. (TA.) [<foreign lang="ar">بِنَفْسِى فُلَانٌ</foreign> is an elliptical phrase sometimes used, for <foreign lang="ar">بِنَفْسِى فُلَانٌ مَفْدِىٌّ</foreign>, which see in art. <foreign lang="ar">فدى</foreign>.]          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  A thing's <hi rend="ital">self;</hi> (S, M, A, K, TA;) used as a corroborative; (S, TA;) its <hi rend="ital">whole,</hi> (Aboo-Is-hák, M, TA,) and <hi rend="ital">essential constituent:</hi> (Aboo-Is-hák, M, A, K, TA:) pl. as above, <foreign lang="ar">أَنْفُسٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">نُفُوسٌ</foreign>. (M.) You say, <foreign lang="ar">رَأَيْتُ فُلَانًا نَفْسَهُ</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">I saw such a one himself,</hi> (S,) and <foreign lang="ar">جَآءَنِى بِنَفْسِهِ</foreign> [or, more properly, <foreign lang="ar">حَآءَنِى هُوَ بِنَفْسِهِ</foreign> (see, under the head of <foreign lang="ar">بِ</foreign>, a remark on that preposition when used in a case of this kind, redundantly,)] <hi rend="ital">He came to me himself.</hi> (S, K.) And <foreign lang="ar">وَلِىَ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">الأَمْرَ بِنَفْسِهِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">He superintended, managed,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">conducted, the affair in his own person</hi>]. (K, in art. <foreign lang="ar">بشر</foreign>, &amp;c.) And <foreign lang="ar">حَدَّثَ نَفْسَهُ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">He talked to himself; soliloquized</hi>]. (Msb, in art. <foreign lang="ar">بلو</foreign>; &amp;c.) And <foreign lang="ar">قَتَلَ فُلَانٌ نَفْسَهُ</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  [<hi rend="ital">Such a one killed himself</hi>]: and <foreign lang="ar">أَهْلَكَ نَفْسَهُ</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">made his whole self to fall into destruction.</hi> (Aboo-Is-hák, M.) And hence, (TA,) from <foreign lang="ar">نَفْسُ الشَّىْءِ</foreign> signifying <foreign lang="ar">ذَاتُهُ</foreign>, (M,) the saying mentioned by Sb, <foreign lang="ar">نَزَلْتُ بِنَفْسِ الجَبَلِ</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  [<hi rend="ital">I alighted in the mountain itself</hi>]: and <foreign lang="ar">نَفْسُ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">الجَبَلِ مُقَابِلِى</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  [<hi rend="ital">The mountain itself is facing me</hi>]. (M, TA.) [Hence also the phrase] <foreign lang="ar">فِى</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">نَفْسِ الأَمْرِ</foreign> [meaning <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">in reality; in the thing itself</hi>]: as in the saying, <foreign lang="ar">قَلَّلَهُ فِى نَفْسِهِ وَإِنْ لَمْ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">يَكُنْ قَلِيلًا فِى نَفْسِ الأَمْرِ</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  [<hi rend="ital">He held it to be little in his mind though it was not little in reality</hi>]. (Msb, art. <foreign lang="ar">قل</foreign>.) The words of the Kur, [v. 116,] <foreign lang="ar">تَعْلَمُ مَا فِى نَفْسِى وَلَا أَعْلَمُ مَا فِى نَفْسِكَ</foreign> mean <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">Thou knowest what is in myself,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">in my essence, and I know not what is in thyself,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">in thine essence:</hi> (Bd, K:) or <hi rend="ital">Thou knowest what I conceal</hi> (M, Bd, Jel) <hi rend="ital">in my</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">نفس</foreign> [or <hi rend="ital">mind</hi>], (Bd, Jel,) <hi rend="ital">and I know not what is in thyself,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">in thine essence, nor that whereof Thou hast the knowledge,</hi> (M.) or <hi rend="ital">what Thou concealest of the things which Thou knowest;</hi> (Bd, Jel;) so that the interpretation is, <hi rend="ital">Thou knowest what I know, and I know not what Thou knowest:</hi> (M:) or <foreign lang="ar">نفس</foreign> is here syn. with <foreign lang="ar">عِنْد</foreign>; and the meaning is, <foreign lang="ar">تَعْلَمُ مَا عِنْدِى وَلَا أَعْلَمُ مَا عِنْدَكَ</foreign>; (K, * TA;) [i. e., <hi rend="ital">Thou knowest what is in my particular place of being, and I know not what is in thy particular place of being;</hi> for] the adverbiality in this instance is that of <foreign lang="ar">مَكَانَة</foreign>, not of <foreign lang="ar">مَكَان</foreign>: (TA:) but the best explanation is that of IAmb, who says that <foreign lang="ar">نفس</foreign> is here syn. with <foreign lang="ar">غَيْب</foreign>; so that the meaning is, <hi rend="ital">Thou knowest</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">غَيْبِى</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">my hidden things,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">what is hidden from me, and I know not thy hidden things,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">what Thou hidest</hi>]; and the correctness of this is testified by the concluding words of the verse, <foreign lang="ar">إِنَّكَ أَنْتَ عَلَّامُ الغُيُوبِ</foreign> [for Thou art he who well knoweth the hidden things]: (TA:) [and here it must be remarked that] <foreign lang="ar">العَيْبُ</foreign>, which occurs afterwards in the K as one of the significations of <foreign lang="ar">النَّفْسُ</foreign>, is a mistake for <foreign lang="ar">الغَيْبُ</foreign>, the word used by IAmb in explaining the above verse. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">A person; a being; an individual;</hi> syn. <pb n="2828"/> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">شَخْصٌ</foreign>; (Msb;) <hi rend="ital">a man,</hi> (Sb, S, M, TA,) <hi rend="ital">altogether, his soul and his body;</hi> (TA;) <hi rend="ital">a living being, altogether.</hi> (Mgh, Msb.) In this sense of <foreign lang="ar">شخص</foreign> it is masc.: (Msb:) or, accord to Lh, the Arabs said, <foreign lang="ar">رَأَيْتُ نَفْسًا وَاحِدَةً</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  [<hi rend="ital">I saw one person</hi>], making it fem.; and in like manner, <foreign lang="ar">رَأَيْتُ نَفْسَيْنِ ثِنْتَيْنِ</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  [<hi rend="ital">I saw two persons</hi>]; but they said, <foreign lang="ar">رَأَيْتُ ثَلَاثَةَ أَنْفُسٍ</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  [<hi rend="ital">I saw three persons</hi>], and so all the succeeding numbers, making it masc.: but, he says, it is allowable to make it masc. in the sing. and dual., and fem. in the pl.: and all this, he says, is related on the authority of Ks: (M:) Sb says, (M.) they said <foreign lang="ar">ثَلَاثَةُ أَنْفُسٍ</foreign>, (S, M,) making it masc., (S,) because they mean by <foreign lang="ar">نفس</foreign> “ a man, ” (S, M,) as is shown also by their saying <foreign lang="ar">نَفْسٌ وَاحِدٌ</foreign>: (M:) but Yoo asserts of Ru-beh, that he said <foreign lang="ar">ثَلَاثُ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">أَنْفُسٍ</foreign>, making <foreign lang="ar">نفس</foreign> fem., like as you say <foreign lang="ar">ثَلَاثُ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">أَعْيُنٍ</foreign>, meaning, of men; and <foreign lang="ar">ثَلَاثَةُ أَشْخُصٍ</foreign>, meaning, of women: and it is said in the Kur, [iv. l, &amp;c.,] <foreign lang="ar">اَلَّذِى خَلَقَكُمْ مِنْ نَفْسٍ وَاحِدَةٍ</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  [<hi rend="ital">who created you from one man</hi>], meaning, Adam. (M.) You also say, <foreign lang="ar">مَا رَأَيْتُ ثَمَّ نَفْسًا</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">I saw not there any one.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">A brother:</hi> (IKh, IB:) <hi rend="ital">a copartner in religion and relationship:</hi> (Bd, xxiv. 61:) <hi rend="ital">a copartner in faith and religion.</hi> (Ibn-'Arafeh.) <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  It is said in the Kur, [xxiv. 61,] <foreign lang="ar">فَإِذَا دَخَلْتُمْ بُيُوتًا فَسَلِّمُوا عَلَى أَنْفُسِكُمْ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">And when ye enter houses, salute ye your brethren:</hi> (IB:) or <hi rend="ital">your copartners in religion and relationship.</hi> (Bd.) And in verse 12 of the same chapter. <foreign lang="ar">بِأَنْفُسِهِمْ</foreign> means <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">Of their copartners in faith and religion.</hi> (Ibn-'Arafeh.)          <sense type="b" n="5">-b5-</sense>  <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">Blood:</hi> (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) [or the <hi rend="ital">life-blood:</hi> in this sense, fem.:] pl. [of pauc. <foreign lang="ar">أَنْفُسٌ</foreign> and of mult.] <foreign lang="ar">نُفُوسٌ</foreign>: (IB:) so called [because the animal soul was believed by the Arabs, as it was by many others in ancient times, (see Gen. ix. 4, and Aristotle, De Anim. i. 2, and Virgil's Æn. ix. 349.) to diffuse itself throughout the body by means of the arteries: or] because the <foreign lang="ar">نَفْس</foreign> [in its proper sense, i. e. the soul,] goes forth with it: (TA:) or because it sustains the whole animal. (Mgh, Msb.) You say, <foreign lang="ar">سَالَتْ نَفْسُهُ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  [<hi rend="ital">His blood flowed</hi>]. (S.) And <foreign lang="ar">نَفْسٌ سَائِلَةٌ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  [<hi rend="ital">Flowing blood</hi>]. (S, A, Mgh.) And <foreign lang="ar">دَفَقَ نَفْسَهُ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">He shed his blood.</hi> (A, TA.)          <sense type="b" n="6">-b6-</sense>  <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  The <hi rend="ital">body.</hi> (S, A, K.)          <sense type="b" n="7">-b7-</sense>  <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  [Sometimes it seems to signify The <hi rend="ital">stomach.</hi> So in the present day. You say, <foreign lang="ar">لَعِبَتْ نَفْسُهُ</foreign>, meaning <hi rend="ital">He was sick in the stomach.</hi> See <foreign lang="ar">غَثَتْ نَفْسُهُ</foreign>, in art. <foreign lang="ar">غثى</foreign>; and <foreign lang="ar">مَذِرَتْ مَعِدَتُهُ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">نَفْسُهُ</foreign>, in art. <foreign lang="ar">مذر</foreign>.]          <sense type="b" n="8">-b8-</sense>  <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  [The <hi rend="ital">pudendum:</hi> so in the present day: in the K, art. <foreign lang="ar">حشو</foreign>, applied to a woman's <hi rend="ital">vulva.</hi>]          <sense type="b" n="9">-b9-</sense>  [From the primary signification are derived several others, of attributes of the rational and animal souls; and such are most of the signification here following.]          <sense type="b" n="10">-b10-</sense>  <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">Knowledge.</hi> (A.) [See, above, an explanation of the words cited from ch. v. verse 116 of the Kur-án.]          <sense type="b" n="11">-b11-</sense>  <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">Pride:</hi> (A, K, TA:) <hi rend="ital">and self-magnification;</hi> syn. <foreign lang="ar">عِزَّةٌ</foreign>. (A, K.)          <sense type="b" n="12">-b12-</sense>  <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">Disdain,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">scorn.</hi> (A, K.)          <sense type="b" n="13">-b13-</sense>  <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">Purpose,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">intention:</hi> or <hi rend="ital">strong determination:</hi> syn. <foreign lang="ar">هِمَّةٌ</foreign>. (A, K.)          <sense type="b" n="14">-b14-</sense>  <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">Will, wish,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">desire.</hi> (A, K.)          <sense type="b" n="15">-b15-</sense>  [<hi rend="ital">Copulation:</hi> see 3, art <foreign lang="ar">رود</foreign>.]          <sense type="b" n="16">-b16-</sense>  [<assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">Stomach,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">appetite.</hi>]          <sense type="b" n="17">-b17-</sense>  <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">An</hi> [<hi rend="ital">evil</hi> or <hi rend="ital">envious</hi>] <hi rend="ital">eye,</hi> (S, M, A, K, TA,) <hi rend="ital">that smites the person</hi> or <hi rend="ital">thing at which it is cast:</hi> pl. <foreign lang="ar">أَنْفُسٌ</foreign>. (TA.) [See 1, last signification.] So in a trad., in which it is said, that the <foreign lang="ar">نَمْلَة</foreign> and the <foreign lang="ar">حُمَة</foreign> and the <foreign lang="ar">نَفْس</foreign> are the only things for which a charm is allowable. (TA.) You say, <foreign lang="ar">أَصَابَتْ فُلَانًا نَفْسٌ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  [<hi rend="ital">An evil</hi> or <hi rend="ital">envious eye smote such a one</hi>]. (S.) And Mohammad said, of a piece of green fat that he threw away, <foreign lang="ar">كَانَ فِيهَا سَبْعَةُ أَنْفُسٍ</foreign>, meaning, <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">There were upon it seven</hi> [<hi rend="ital">evil</hi> or <hi rend="ital">envious</hi>] <hi rend="ital">eyes.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="18">-b18-</sense>  <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">Strength of make, and hardiness,</hi> of a man: and <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">closeness of texture, and strength,</hi> of a garment or piece of cloth. (M.)       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  <hi rend="ital">Punishment.</hi> (A, K.) Ex. <foreign lang="ar">وَيُحَذِّرُكُم ٱللّٰهُ نَفْسَهُ</foreign>, (K,) in the Kur, [iii. 27 and 28, meaning, <hi rend="ital">And God maketh you to fear his punishment</hi>]; accord. to F; but others say that the meaning is, <hi rend="ital">Himself.</hi> (TA.)       <sense type="A" n="3">-A3-</sense>  <hi rend="ital">A quantity</hi> (S, M, K,) <hi rend="ital">of</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">قَرَظ</foreign>, and <hi rend="ital">of other things, with which hides are tanned,</hi> (S, K,) <hi rend="ital">sufficient for one tanning:</hi> (S, M, K:) or <hi rend="ital">enough for two tannings:</hi> (TA:) or <hi rend="ital">a handful thereof:</hi> (M:) pl. <foreign lang="ar">أَنَفُسٌ</foreign>. (M.) You say, <foreign lang="ar">هَبْ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">لِى نفْسًا مِنْ دِبَاغٍ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Give thou to me a quantity of material for tanning sufficient for one tanning,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">for two tannings,</hi> &amp;c.]. (S.)    </entryFree>2b:T2b7f,<entryFree id="n40257" key="نَفَسٌ" type="main">

                  </form> [<hi rend="ital">Breath;</hi>] <hi rend="ital">what is drawn in by the airpassages in the nose,</hi> [or <hi rend="ital">by the mouth,</hi>] <hi rend="ital">to the inside, and emitted,</hi> (Msb;) <hi rend="ital">what comes forth from a living being in the act of</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">تَنَفُّس</foreign>. (Mgh:) or the <hi rend="ital">exit of wind from the nose and the mouth:</hi> (M:) pl. <foreign lang="ar">أَنْفَاسٌ</foreign>. (S, M, A. Mgh, Msb, K.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  <hi rend="ital">A gentle air:</hi> pl. as above. (M, Msb.) You say also, <foreign lang="ar">نَفَسُ الرِّيحِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">The breath of the wind</hi>]: and <foreign lang="ar">نَفَسُ الرَّوْصَةِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">the sweet</hi> [<hi rend="ital">breath</hi> or] <hi rend="ital">odour</hi> [<hi rend="ital">of the meadow,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">of the garden,</hi> &amp;c.]. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  [Hence, app., its application in the phrase] <foreign lang="ar">نَفَسَ السَّاعَةِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">The blast of the</hi> last <hi rend="ital">hour;</hi> meaning,] <hi rend="ital">the end of time.</hi> (Kr, M.)          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  [Hence also, <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">Speech:</hi> and <hi rend="ital">kind speech:</hi> (see an ex. voce <foreign lang="ar">أَمْلَحَ</foreign>:) so in the present day.]          <sense type="b" n="5">-b5-</sense>  [And <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">Voice,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">a sweet voice, in singing:</hi> so in the present day.]          <sense type="b" n="6">-b6-</sense>  <hi rend="ital">A gulp.</hi> or <hi rend="ital">as much as is swallowed at once in drinking:</hi> (S, L, K:) but this requires consideration; for in one <foreign lang="ar">نَفَس</foreign> a man takes a number of gulps, more or less according to the length or shortness of his breath, so that we [sometimes] see a man drink [the contents of] a large vessel in one <foreign lang="ar">نَفَس</foreign>, at a number of gulps: (L:) [therefore it signifies sometimes, if not always, <hi rend="ital">a draught,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">as much as is swallowed without taking breath:</hi>] pl. as above. (S.) You say, <foreign lang="ar">إِكْرَعْ فِى الإِتَآءِ نَفَسًا أَوْ نَفَسَيْنِ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  [<hi rend="ital">Put thou thy mouth into the vessel and drink</hi>] <hi rend="ital">a gulp,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">two gulps:</hi> [or <hi rend="ital">a draught,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">two draughts:</hi>] and exceed not that. (S; And <foreign lang="ar">شَربْتُ نَفَسًا</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">وَأَنْفَاسًا</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  [<hi rend="ital">I drank a gulp, and gulps:</hi> or <hi rend="ital">a draught, and draughts</hi>]. (A.) And <foreign lang="ar">فُلَانٌ شَرِبَ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">الإِنَآءَ كُلَّهُ عَلَى نَفَسٍ وَاحِدٍ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  [<hi rend="ital">Such a one drank the whole contents of the vessel at one gulp</hi> or <hi rend="ital">at one draught</hi>]. (L.)          <sense type="b" n="7">-b7-</sense>  <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  Every <hi rend="ital">resting between two draughts:</hi> (M, TA:) [pl. as above.] You say, <foreign lang="ar">شَرِبَ بِنَفَسٍ وَاحِدٍ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  [<hi rend="ital">He drank with one resting between draughts</hi>]. (A.) And <foreign lang="ar">شَربَ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">بِثَلَاثَةِ أَنْفَاسٍ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  [<hi rend="ital">He drank with three restings between draughts</hi>]. (A. K.) [And hence,] <foreign lang="ar">شَرَابٌ ذُو نَفَسِ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">Beverage in which is ampleness,</hi> [<hi rend="ital">so that one pauses while drinking it, to take breath,</hi>] <hi rend="ital">and which satisfies thirst.</hi> (IAar, K.) And <foreign lang="ar">شَرَابٌ غَيْرُ ذِى نَفَسٍ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">Beverage of disagreeable taste,</hi> (A, K, *) <hi rend="ital">changed in taste and odour,</hi> (K,) <hi rend="ital">in drinking which one does not take breath</hi> (A, K) <hi rend="ital">when he has tasted it;</hi> (K;) <hi rend="ital">taking a first draught, as much as will keep in the remains of life, and not returning to it.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="8">-b8-</sense>  [And hence it is said that] <foreign lang="ar">نَفَسٌ</foreign> signifies <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">Satisfaction,</hi> or the <hi rend="ital">state of being satisfied, with drink;</hi> syn. <foreign lang="ar">دِىَّ</foreign>. (IAar, K.)          <sense type="b" n="9">-b9-</sense>  [Hence also.] <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">Plenty, and redundance.</hi> So in the saying <foreign lang="ar">إِنّ فِى المَآءِ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">نَفَسًا لِى وَلَكَ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Verily in the water is plenty, and redundance, for me and for thee</hi>]. (Lh, M.)          <sense type="b" n="10">-b10-</sense>  <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">A wide space:</hi> (TA:) <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">a distance</hi> (A.) You say, <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَ الفَر يقَيْن نَفَسٌ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">Between the two parties is a wide space.</hi> (TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنِى وَبَيْنَهٌ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">نَفَسٌ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">Between me and him is a distance.</hi> (A.)          <sense type="b" n="11">-b11-</sense>  <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">Ample scope for action &amp;c.;</hi> and <hi rend="ital">a state in which is ample scope for action &amp;c., </hi> syn. <foreign lang="ar">سعةٌ</foreign>, (S, M, A, Mgh, K,) and <foreign lang="ar">فُسْحَةٌ</foreign>, (A, K,) in an affair. (S, M, A, K.) You say, <foreign lang="ar">لَك فِى هٰذَا نَفَسٌ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">There is ample scope for action &amp;c. for thee in this.</hi> (Mgh.) And <foreign lang="ar">أَنْتَ فِى نَفِس مِنْ أَمْرِكَ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  [<hi rend="ital">Thou art in a state in which is ample scope for action &amp;c. with respect to thine affair.</hi> (S, M.) And <foreign lang="ar">إِعْملْ وَأَنْتَ فِى نَفَسٍ مِنْ أَمْرِكَ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">Work thou while thou art in a state in which is ample scope for action &amp;c.</hi> (<foreign lang="ar">فِى فُسْحَةٍ وَسَعَة</foreign>) <hi rend="ital">with respect to thine affair,</hi> before extreme old age, and diseases, and calamities. (TA.) See also <foreign lang="ar">نُفْسَةٌ</foreign>.          <sense type="b" n="12">-b12-</sense>  <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">Length.</hi> (M.)                   <foreign lang="ar">فِى أَجَلِى</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  [<hi rend="ital">Add thou to me length in my term</hi>

                  <hi rend="ital">of life</hi>]: (M:) or <hi rend="ital">lengthen thou my term of life.</hi> (TA.) You say also,   
      <foreign lang="ar">فِى عُمُرِهِ <ref cref="n40257-1" target="مُتَنَفَّسٌ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n40271"/></foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  [<hi rend="ital">In his life is length:</hi> see 5]. (A, TA.)          <sense type="b" n="13">-b13-</sense>  The pl., in the accus. case, also signifies <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">Time after time.</hi> So in the saying of the poet, <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">عَيْنَىَّ جُودَا عَبْرَةً أَنْفَاسَا</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> [<hi rend="ital">O my two eyes, pour forth a flow of tears time after time</hi>]. (S.)       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">نَفَسٌ</foreign> is also a subst. put in the place of the proper inf. n. of <foreign lang="ar">نَفَّسَ</foreign>; and is so used in the two following sayings, (K, TA,) of Mohammad. (TA.) <foreign lang="ar">لَا تَسبُوُّا الرِّيحَ فَإِنَّهَا مِنْ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">نَفَسِ الرَّحْمٰنِ</foreign>, i. e. <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  [<hi rend="ital">Revile not ye the wind, for</hi>] <hi rend="ital">it is a means whereby the Compassionate removes grief,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">sorrow,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">anxiety,</hi> (K, TA,) <hi rend="ital">and raises the clouds,</hi> (TA,) <hi rend="ital">and scatters the rain, and dispels dearth,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">drought.</hi> (K, TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">أَجِدُ نَفَسَ رَبَِّكُمْ مِنْ قِبَلِ اليَمَنِ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">I perceive your Lord's removal of grief,</hi> &amp;c., <hi rend="ital">from the direction of El-Yemen:</hi> meaning, through the aid and hospitality of the people of El-Medeeneh, who were of El-Yemen; (K, TA;) i. e., of the Ansár, who were of [the tribe of] El-Azd, from ElYemen. (TA.) It is [said by some to be] a metaphor, from <foreign lang="ar">نَفَسُ الهَوَآءِ</foreign>, which the act of breathing draws back into the inside, so that its heat becomes cooled and moderated: or from <foreign lang="ar">نَفَسُ الرِّيِح</foreign>, which one scents, so that thereby he refreshes himself: or from <foreign lang="ar">نَفَسُ الرَّوْضَةِ</foreign>. (TA.) You also say, <foreign lang="ar">مَا لِى نَفَسٌ</foreign>, meaning, <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">There is not for me any removal,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">clearing away, of grief.</hi> (A.)       <sense type="A" n="3">-A3-</sense>  It is also used as an epithet, signifying <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">Long;</hi> (AZ, K;) applied to speech, (K,) and to writing, or book, or letter. (AZ, K.)    </entryFree>2c:T7fc,<entryFree id="n40260" key="نُفَسَآءُ" type="main">

                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">نُفَسَآءُ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> (Th, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K, &amp;c.) and <foreign lang="ar">نَفَسَآءُ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">نَفْسَآءُ</foreign> (M, K) <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">A</hi> woman <hi rend="ital">in the state following childbirth:</hi> (S, M, * Mgh, * Msb, * K:) or <hi rend="ital">bringing forth:</hi> and <hi rend="ital">pregnant:</hi> and <hi rend="ital">menstruating:</hi> (Th, M:) and <foreign lang="ar">نَافِسٌ</foreign> signifies the same; (Msb;) and so

(K.)    </entryFree>2d:T660,<entryFree id="n40263" key="نِفَاسٌ" type="main">

(Mgh.)          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  A poet says, (namely, Ows Ibn-Hajar, O, in art. <foreign lang="ar">طرق</foreign>,) <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">لَنَا صَرْخَةٌ ثُمَّ إِسْكَاتَةٌ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">كَمَا طَرَّقَتْ بِنِفَاسٍ بِكِرْ</foreign>
                     </L>

(S.)    </entryFree>2e:Tdbd,<entryFree id="n40265" key="نَفِيسٌ" type="main">

                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">نَفِيسٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> A thing <hi rend="ital">high in estimation; of high account; excellent;</hi> (Lh, M, Msb, TA;) [<hi rend="ital">highly prized; precious; valuable; and therefore</hi> (TA) <hi rend="ital">desired with emulation,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">in much request;</hi> (S, K, TA;) <hi rend="ital">good, goodly,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">excellent, in its kind;</hi> (TA;) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n40265-1" target="نَافِسٌ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n40266"/></foreign> signifies the same, (M,) and so does   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n40265-2" target="مُنْفِسٌ" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n40269"/></foreign>, (Lh, M, A, Msb, K,) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n40265-3" target="مَنْفُوسٌ" n="3" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n40270"/></foreign>: (K:) it signifies thus when applied to property, as well as other things; as also   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n40265-4" target="مَنْفِسٌ" n="4" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>: (Lh, M:) and, when so applied, <hi rend="ital">of which one is avaricious,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">tenacious:</hi> (M:) or
